utterances: And like her, are you going out for dinner?
Well, no. I actually - I have - I'm a fisherman and a hunter and I have quite a bit of stuff defrosting in my freezer.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That I've spent a lot of money to go get, so I'm trying to eat some of that.
But I thought you might find it interesting that I've been out of power long - just long enough that I'm no longer walking into the dark rooms and flipping the switch anyway.
(Soundbite of laughter)
It takes a while to break that habit, I suppose.
Well, it's four days for me, so that's what a slow learner I am.
Well, venison for dinner and venison for breakfast and venison for lunch?
Yeah - plus some crappy and bass - yeah.
Well, it sounds like at least you're eating well.
Yes, sir, I'm eating fine.
Well, thanks very much for the call.
Take care of yourself.
You're welcome.
I enjoy your show.
Thank you very much for that.
Bye.
We're talking with people in the midst of the ice storm that hit much of Midwest, 800-989-8255.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And there's an e-mail here.
We have Steve(ph) in Little Rock, Arkansas.
Neal, a good portion of Arkansas suffered two ice storms in late December of 2000 not unlike those of today.
I do a lot of camping so surviving the lost of electric service was not as bad for us as for some of my neighbors.
To those in the icy areas, I say hang in there.
Take note of what equipment you lack and purchase it when you get the chance and thank all of the out-of-town linemen, tree trimmers and rescue folks you see.
Be patient.
It takes weeks if not months to get back to normal.
I'm not sure that's an encouragement to a lot of people these days.
Let's see if we can go now to - this is Ash(ph).
Ash with us also from Tulsa, Oklahoma.
Good afternoon, Neal.
Good afternoon.
Pleasure to speak with you.
Well, thanks for calling.
Well, yeah, I'd like to say, you know, reflect everything that all the Tulsans have said about the city.
When the power went out Monday morning, it got so dark - you just - you couldn't see.
And then, the trees that fell on the street - it's been a huge problem because you'd come up on them all of a sudden and you couldn't see them.
But it's, you know, four days into it and I am still without power but I'm getting by.
It's pretty cold out here right now and the only time I have a chance to even find out what's going on is when I get in the car to listen to the radio.
So when the NPR affiliate here in Tulsa said that upwards of 160,000 PSO customers are without power, that was pretty alarming.
That's the first news I've heard of it in four days.

But I would also like to agree with the e-mailer from Little Rock and say please thank all the linemen that are out there and all of the people cleaning up the trees because they're, you know, they're sacrificing their time with their family during the holidays and doing a great job.
And even though I'm without power and I'm expecting to have no power for at least a week, it's still good to know that they're here for - that they're doing everything they can to help us out.
Tell us though, what was it like to drive on the ice day one, day two?
It was - at night, absolutely and stunningly beautiful because it was very eerie to see a major city like this without lights.
It was so dark.
You could barely see even with your headlights on in the car.
And during the daytime, it's not so beautiful because, like everybody else is saying, many of the trees that give the neighborhoods their distinct Tulsa look are gone.
They've completely fallen down or will never look the same.
And - but at night without the power, beautiful.
Ash, thanks very much and good luck to you.
Thank you.
So long.
Let's see if we can talk now with Sandra(ph).
Sandra with us from Norman, Oklahoma.
That's right.
Hi, Neal.
Hi.
How are you?
Good.
How are you?
I'm well.
Thank you.
But well, we haven't had much (unintelligible) weather here in Washington.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, I hear there is more coming towards the north so maybe you'll get some of it.
Well, we don't look forward to it.
So far, it's just been a little light rain though there may be something this weekend.
But you could have another couple of inches, what, tomorrow.
Right.
Which I'm not looking forward to.
This coming weekend is my graduation at the University of Oklahoma and so I have lots of family and friends that are supposed to be traveling this way and I'm like, oh, great.
No one's going to see me graduate.
At least, you'll remember it though.
(Soundbite of laughter)
True.
It's been really fun though preparing this week with the weather because this is our finals week at the University of Oklahoma.
And we've had classes cancelled the first part of the week but not the rest of the week, which affected my schedule.

And I was out talking with a friend recently and we were discussing how we're sitting next to her fireplace where we didn't have firewood so we dismantled an old box-spring and use the boxes like the wood, all of the mattress to keep warm.
(Soundbite of laughter)
So at the same time, you feel like you're, you know, somebody mentioned, you know, post-apocalyptic and you're studying by firelight feeling like Abraham Lincoln?
Yes.
It is very much post-apocalyptic out here.
I mean, like, just walking around campus alone, it's like you have to really like step over trees and make sure that nothing is going to fall where you're walking.
And do you have enough blankets and comforters and that sort of things so you can stay warm enough to sleep at night?
Yes.
I've been like currently right now, I'm like in a gown jacket as well as one of your other callers and have my gloves on and blankets around me and I've been okay.
And your neighbors?
As far as I know, they're okay.
I live in a complex.
And, I mean, when it first started happening whenever the trees were popping, everybody would run out and be like, what is that?
But as far as I can tell, everyone seems to be doing well.
Well, good luck on your exams and we'll be thinking of you during graduation.
